messageBody:
On Sun, 2 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:

> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Curt Sampson [mailto:yahoo_sucks@...]
> [...]
> > > Testability is an aspectual concern, not really a part of an
> > > object being modeled.
> >
> > I disagree.
>
> So maybe you would say logging isn't an aspectual concern either. You are
> talking about aspects in a system, which is exactly my point.

Well, the aspectual Java papers are on my list of things to read very, very
soon (i.e., I'm carrying them around in my bag every day), but unfortunately
I've not gotten around to reading them. So I probably don't really understand
what you mean by "aspectual" in this case.

However, from having looked at examples of Aspect-J, particularly the
logging one, I can say that what I do in terms of making objects more
testable is not the same, because it's not something you implement the
same way across lots of objects (the way logging the parameters to a
method would be).

Basically, I change not just the code itself, but even the design of
the code in order to make it easier to test. I do things like changing
from static factory methods in individual classes to non-static factory
methods in a centralized factory object so that I can use a different
implemenation of that factory when I do unit testing. I don't really see
how that's an aspectual thing, except in the most vague and general sense.

This ability to write your code differently so that you can test things
more easily (or at all, sometimes!) is to my mind one of the most
powerful aspects of having the same person writing tests and code at the
same time, rather than testing after the code is done.

> You say it's easier or your preference to represent testability as
> addtional mixed in methods here and there in the objects. I don't like
> that. But it seems like it's a matter of taste.

That's only one of the strategies I'll use to make an object more testable.

I wonder if someone's already written up a set of design patterns for typical
problems and solutions in XP-style testing.
